Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: Second Assistant U.S. Secretary of State

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, La, Jan'y 27, 1881.
Mr. J. H. Smyth to the Second Ass't Sec'y, State.
Change of Grand Bassa from a Commercial Agency to a Consular Agency, as to.

Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, La, Jan'y 27, 1881.

In answer to your No. 18, date Dec. 18, 1880, consular series, I have respectfully to submit that, I am of opinion that the reduction of the Commercial Agency of Grand Bassa to that of a Consular Agency would be a reform in the direction of securing more satisfactory statistical information as to the commercial relations of Liberia, because the greatest number of vessels engaged in Liberian trade
Hon. W. Hunter,
Second Assistant Secretary,
Washington, D.C.
trade enter at Grand Bassa, and because our trade would be increased.

The Commercial Agency, if changed, would be likely to create in the officer an interest in promoting our commercial relations from harmonious action between the Agent and this office, which does not exist from the nature of a Commercial Agency.

Grand Bassa is from four to five hours by steam from Monrovia, the distance being 60 miles, and by sailing vessel from seven to ten hours. This port may be reached by the beach, by open boat, by steamer or sailing vessel. Every week some one
one of these means of reaching the port is offered.

With sentiments of high esteem, I am, Sir,
Your obedient servant,
Jno. H. Smyth, U.S. Consul General.
